"She has to protect them, keep them from being eaten, be like a fortress" Why?
It's extraordinary to me that throughout the biological sciences, we consistently use this terminology.
So much of our ideas regarding activities of flora and fauna, particular those which relate to survival, are predicated upon the notion that life is somehow preferable to death
Why should this be so in a purposeless universe?
Why does she "have to protect them"? Why is death a negative outcome in a purposeless universe? Considering the effort which living things expend in order to stay alive,
perhaps they know something we dont.

Thank you for a fun and well-produced video! There are a couple of issues I suggest you address. Firstly, some of the trees and their cones shown are not, as they are described in the video, actually pines. The cone on a hemlock is not a pine cone, it is a hemlock cone. The tallest trees on earth do not reproduce with pine cones, they reproduce with redwood cones (for that matter, redwoods are not, as the video states, the largest living things on Earth; there are fungi that dwarf redwoods!). It is true that cones are fairly primitive compared to flowering plant reproduction, but compared to moss and fern reproduction, conifer sex is pretty advanced. It is a stretch to label cone reproduction with a blanket label of "primitive". Cone reproduction is fairly advanced in many ways. I think the quality of the imagery, production, and narration of these videos deserves an equally valid look into the core science being presented. Thanks for considering these recommendations!

How about a video on geochemistry?  How do particular kinds of rocks form?  Or, why do very different kinds of rocks form in the same area?  The Sierras are a grand composite of different rock formation stories. It's big and complicated, but I'm sure you could do a great job of explaining how it all comes to be.

As a conifer dork, a tree surgeon of ten years and having worked in two of the most well known public gardens/botanical institutions in the UK, I approve of this video, but the pedant in me can't accept the casual use of 'pine cone'. I mean, you've got shots of Sequoiadendron, Cupressus and Tsuga while calling them all pine cones. I know you're catering for the lay person, but my years of teaching horticultural trainees die hard. Nevertheless, another excellent video. More tree videos!
